title: OER Research Hub Examines OER Impact at U.S. Community Colleges
segmentation: Alright, good afternoon everyone.
Did you enjoy your first day at the conference?
Been a lot of a lot of really interesting material covered.

I'm unidale I'm the Community College outreach director at the Open Courseware Consortium an it's my pleasure to be presenting here today with Doctor Rob Farrow from Open University about RO ER impact research collaboration.
And.
Rob is going to tell you most of most of the work that we did around the collaboration, but I wanted to tell you a little bit about community colleges, which is my focus.
How many of you are familiar with the model of a Community College such as we have in the United States and Canada?
Right, I see two or three of you out there.
OK, well, good, I'll let you know a little bit about that.
Then the community colleges are two year colleges within the higher education system started in the United States and is also in Canada and in the United States.
We have about 1200 colleges in our 50 States and we have approximately 8 million students who are enrolled about 60% of those are part time students.
Many of our students actually have full time jobs or families.
Their adult learners for the most part, not entirely our highest percentage of students.
45% of our students are between 25 and 39, so we do tend to have more of the adult learner.
What else can I tell you our our focus at Community colleges is Open Access.
So as our Under Secretary of Education has said, we accept the top 100% of students, which means we accept everyone which.
Adds to the excitement are three are three.
Main focus is our transfer, so we provide a transfer curriculum to the University.
So we provide the 1st two years before students transfer to the University for a full bachelors.
We also work very heavily with workforce development and skills so we have students who come in to get a one or a two year.

Workforce certificate and go out into the workforce, and often those students come back and they will complete an associates degree and move on to the University and the third one is that we work with students who may come in who need remediation.
They may not be quite ready for college level work or they may have.

Additional needs around language so we have English as a second language courses and it may be cultural enrichment, so we serve a very wide population and affordability is a really key piece of that for our students.
Often the textbooks are nearly as expensive as the tuition, so that really doubles the cost of attendance for our students.
And there was some recent research published.
In interviews with students, not only at the community colleges, but also at our universities, and about 65% of students don't purchase instructional materials due to cost.
So it's a pretty high percentage.

About 50% of students report that they take fewer classes, or they take different classes because of these costs, and about 95% of these students who haven't purchased their instructional materials feel that it has had a negative effect upon their grades.
So the use of open educational resources by our faculty really helps our students to be successful.
And that said, we started working with Open University about a year and a half ago to find out about how open educational resources was impacting faculty and students.
And I just wanted to talk really quickly about the three hypothesis that we developed together.
And that these were our research questions.
Does Zoe are actually improve teaching practice.
An I think we can conservatively say yes, Rob will give you the details on that one.
The other thing we wanted to find out is does O ER usage affect institutional policy?
So as faculty adopt, O ER, is this having an effect on our Board of Trustees?
Are administrators?
Are they supporting open Policy's at a higher level as they see students be more successful?
So we have some evidence to support that, but it's still an evolving question.
And finally, our students and institutions saving money with the use of O ER an.
Is it making education more equitable?
An there is certainly some evidence to support students savings and we're investigating further how that affects the institution.
And now I'll turn it over to Rob.

Thanks Tina, so as soon as I said the work that we've been doing is collaborative between the Community College Consortium for Area and the area research or project which is based at the Open Universe.
If you want to know more about the project, the addresses are we our research hub.org.
But basically we have a research team that works in conjunction with people around the world to gather data about what's actually happening in different contexts in different sectors.
So in this case I'm going to be talking mainly about the results of a survey.
We did.
The survey was developed last spring was deployed last May, and rolled out a number of different colleges up till about January this year.
So we've been working on the analysis of those figures in the summer.
We're going to be working on analysis of the qualitative data, so we've done a lot of interviews, classroom situations, field trips, that kind of thing.
So I'm going to be talking mainly about.
The survey results here.
Most of the surveys went around for college faculty, most of whom are experienced teachers, so most of them had at least seven years of at least seven years of experience.
84% and 96% had postgraduate degrees, so it's not people who are just starting teaching and experimenting with.
They are.
It's established teachers, most of whom teaching full time.
Now there's a very long version of this presentation.
This is the very short version, so about half sorry.

Most of the people had used some sort of area, but only 1/4 of those had created every are most of them reported a positive effect on their teaching practice, mainly around peer collaboration and improved subject knowledge.
So college chooses are using every are to improve their subject knowledge by their own subject and other subjects as well.
Over 40% of the people we surveyed said that they thought we are use LED directly to improve reflection on their own practice.

So there's something about we are used which is not just down to the ovr itself, but the opportunity in the space that it gives to reflect more about how you teach and why choose this resource rather than this resource.
If you could create a resource, would it look like and these kind of things?
They also identified a number of positive effects for learners.
So things like learners having more autonomy.
Less dependence on others and taking Aleve for themselves.
Some other results we asked whether they thought we always saving their institution, any money, roughly.
Roughly 2/3 felt students save money, but the figure was lower for institutions.
About 1/3 of the people we asked thought that we always helping students sustain in college, but a larger number thought that it wasn't having an effect at all.
Interesting, the only around half of the people who create RAR do so under an open license that was considerably smaller than the number of people that thought open licensing was important.
So one of the things we found was that lots of people thought open licensing was important, but far fewer actually practiced it.
And you can speculate on the reasons, the reasons why.
A lot of colleges there are kind of korevaar advocates, and often you find there's a similar kind of the opposite pole.
A core of people who are kind of resistant and against it.
So this is the poster if you look for it in the in the next room it's it's quite simple to understand rather than a lot of text and you'll see the actual figures there.
And if you have any questions about it, please do ask either myself or you know.
Thanks for listening.
